of in vitro via 3D printing plasmonic nanoparticles SERS 3D tumor models dECM-supporting bath H2020 European Research Council 10.13039/100010663 ERC-2023-POC 101138255 3DTUMOUR H2020 European Research Council 10.13039/100010663 ERC-AdG-2017 787510 4DBIOSERS H2020 Marie Sklodowska-Curie Actions 10.13039/100010665 101105300 Ministerio de Ciencia, Innovación y Universidades 10.13039/100014440 FPU-05867 European Regional Development Fund 10.13039/501100008530 PID2023-151281OB-I00 Agencia Estatal de Investigación 10.13039/501100011033 IJC2019-040827-I pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes document-id-old-9 se5c02344 document-id-new-14 se5c02344 production-flag-MathML-config-version 3 production-flag-journal-citation-display-style acs-titles production-flag-journal-date-display-style dates-used-rcd-rvd-acc production-flag-si-avail yes document-id-alt-64 e5db894e147406bd3336bb0d853e489cc7cb49b87dac7573ce5ad11e58643d67  In vitro in vitro i.e etc  in vitro The extracellular matrix (ECM)
composition in the tumor microenvironment
(TME) and tumor-stroma interactions have been reported to drive tumor
progression and metastasis, leading to poor clinical outcomes.  in vitro  e.g etc We propose that this model might assist in the
identification of
cancer biomarkers and high-throughput therapeutic screening. However,
studying cellular response to therapeutics in complex 3D cell models
with spatial and temporal control remains challenging and requires
techniques with high sensitivity. In this regard, surface-enhanced
Raman spectroscopy (SERS) allows for the identification of relevant
biomarkers in complex biological settings.   Following a similar rationale,
we hypothesized that plasmonic hydrogels,
designed for in situ e.g Results
and Discussion Gold nanorods were chosen as
the plasmonic substrate because of
their tunable localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) through defined
synthesis parameters. In particular, our AuNRs have an aspect ratio
of 2.9 ± 0.5, which leads to an LSPR mode at 785 nm ( Figure S1A,B 2+  Figure 1 Figures S2 and S3 1 (A) Schematic representation of the thiol–ene reaction
to
promote orthogonal photo-cross-linking of the thiolated alginate-methacrylated
carboxymethyl cellulose (TALG-MCMC) ink. (B) Flow curve of the TALG-MCMC
ink showing shear thinning behavior with decreasing apparent viscosity
over increasing shear rates. (C) In situ For the preparation of the plasmonic ink (TALG-MCMC
ink), TALG
and MCMC, both at 2% (w/v) concentration, were added to a colloidal
dispersion of AuNRs ([Au 0 Figure Figure S4 2 Figure S5A 2+ Figure S5B To ensure printability, the rheological properties of the resulting
mixture were assessed, including viscosity and ink flow, kinetics
of the photoinitiated thiol–ene reaction (photorheology), and
viscoelastic behavior. The flow curve of TALG-MCMC ink is shown in Figure G G Figure S6A G G Figure G G 2 ca Figure S6B G G G G G G Figure S6C Plasmonic pillars were subsequently printed within
a bath of porcine
dECM using the AuNR-loaded TALG-MCMC ink ( Figure Experimental Section Figure Figure S7A Figure S7B Figure Figure 2 (A) Schematic design
of plasmonic pillars distributed inside a
dECM. (B) Top and lateral view of the plasmonic pillars in dECM. (C)
SEM micrograph showing the interface between a plasmonic pillar and
the surrounding dECM. (D) SEM micrograph of a selected area in a plasmonic
pillar, showing the presence of well-defined AuNRs (inset) within
the material. The sensing performance of plasmonic
pillars embedded
in dECM was
first tested by incubating the whole system with different concentrations
of 6-TG in cDMEM. To do so, the different solutions were added on
top of the models and incubated at 37 °C. The mechanism of action
of 6-TG is represented in Figure 3 (A) MTAP metabolic pathway in normal cells (top) and MTAP-deficient
cells (bottom), resulting in the increased incorporation of 6-TG into
DNA in the latter. Abbreviations: MTA, methylthioadenosine; MTAP,
methylthioadenosine phosphorylase; PRPP, 5′-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate;
6-TG, 6-thioguanine. (B) Characteristic SERS spectrum of 6-TG. (C)
Optical microscope image of the pillar and the corresponding SERS
intensity xy map for the peak recorded at 1303 cm –1 –1 –1 The performance of the
dECM-embedded plasmonic
pillars was evaluated
by monitoring the intensities of the characteristic SERS peaks of
6-TG at different regions of the tumor model after incubation with
6-TG in cDMEM. The structure of 6-TG comprises a purine ring bearing
an amino and a thiol group that can coordinate with Au, favoring chemical
interaction with AuNRs and resulting in a well-defined SERS profile
( Figure –1 –1 Table S1  –1 Figure Figure Figure Figure S8 Next, we aimed to print the
plasmonic pillars while preserving
the core/shell architecture of the core-stroma model, as well as the
viability of the cells embedded in the dECM ( Figure 2 Figure Figure S9 Figure Figure Figure S10 Figure S11 4 (A) Design of the 3D
breast cancer model with integrated hydrogel
pillars containing plasmonic AuNR sensors. (B) Maximum intensity projection
image acquired by fluorescence confocal microscopy, showing the printed
plasmonic sensors (black circles) in the core and stromal compartments
of the model without disrupting the core/shell architecture. HBFs
are labeled with Deep Red (in pink); MDA-MB-231 cancer cells are labeled
with CMF 2 Finally, we aimed to demonstrate the application
of SERS to monitor
the consumption of the antitumoral drug 6-TG. Therefore, the 3D core/stroma
model including the sensing pillars was incubated with a 400 μM
6-TG solution (1% v/v DMSO/cDMEM). This concentration was chosen considering
the cytotoxicity observed in 2D cell cultures ( Figure S8 Figure –1 Figure –1 Figure Figures S12 5 (A, B) Representative SERS intensity maps for
the 1303 cm –1 –1 P P P Conclusions The present work showcases
the use of plasmonic
hydrogels to introduce
sensors into complex 3D in vitro via in situ via Experimental
section Materials Acetone (≥99.5%), alginic acid sodium
salt (alginate, MW 150,000 g/mol), l 2 4 2 2 4 2 4 2 4 2 4 3 2 Synthesis of Gold Nanorods AuNRs
were prepared according
to well-established procedures. 4 4 3 4 Synthesis of Functionalized Polymers Synthesis of Thiolated
Alginate (TALG) Thiolated alginate
(TALG) was prepared following a reported procedure with some modifications. 2 Synthesis of Methacrylated Carboxymethyl
Cellulose (MCMC) Methacrylated carboxymethyl cellulose (MCMC)
was obtained following
a reported protocol. 2 Preparation TALG-MCMC Ink The preparation of the ink
required further purification of AuNRs by centrifugation at 8000 rpm
and redispersion in MilliQ water to remove excess CTAB. Then, 40 mg
of methacrylated carboxymethylcellulose (MCMC) and 40 mg of thiolated
alginate (TALG) were dissolved into 1.6 mL of AuNRs colloidal dispersion
(1.9 mM). Then, 400 μL of CaCl 2 0 Characterization of AuNRs Ultraviolet–Visible
Absorbance Spectroscopy The colloidal dispersions of AuNRs
were characterized by UV–vis
spectroscopy, using a Cary 60 UV–vis spectrophotometer from
Agilent. Transmission Electron Microscopy The morphology and
dimensions of AuNRs were characterized by TEM with a JEOL JEM-2100F
(UHR) transmission electron microscope. All samples were prepared
by placing a drop of 3 μL of the colloidal solution onto a TEM
grid and drying at RT before imaging. Characterization of the
Polymers Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy ( 1 The chemical structure of the synthesized polymers was determined
through 1 2 Fourier Transform-Infrared
Spectroscopy (FTIR) FTIR
studies were conducted using ATR-FTIR Bruker INVENIO X. The spectrometer
is equipped with an accessory featuring a single-reflection monolithic
diamond for measuring attenuated total reflectance (ATR). Both polymers
were characterized by directly placing a small amount of the dried
sample on the ATR crystal, ensuring full coverage of the crystal surface.
The background was automatically corrected by the software and the
spectrum was collected from 450 to 4000 cm –1 Ellman’s Test To determine the number of thiols
incorporated to alginate, Ellman’s test was performed. First,
40 mg of TALG was diluted into 250 μL of reaction buffer. In
parallel, three test tubes were prepared, each containing 50 μL
of Ellman’s reagent solution (4 mg DTNB/mL reaction buffer)
and 2.5 mL of reaction buffer. Then, the TALG-containing solutions
were added into the previous test tubes for incubation for 15 min
at room temperature. Finally, 200 μL of each solution were added
to a 96-well plate to record the absorbance at 412 nm using Synergy
H1 Hybrid Multi-Mode Microplate Reader from BioTek. The absorbance
values were used to calculate the amount of free thiols according
to a calibration curve obtained using cysteine as standard. Characterization of the TALG-MCMC Hydrogel Rheology Rheological
measurements were performed using
a Physica MCR 302 rheometer equipped with a UV curing lamp (Anton
Paar). Two different geometries and measurement configurations were
used for the TALG-MCMC ink and TALG-MCMC cross-linked hydrogel. A
conventional parallel plate (geometry PP25, Ø25 mm) was used
for the TALG-MCMC ink measurements, and 200 μL of the ink was
placed between the plate and the measuring plate with 0.1 mm gap.
In contrast, a sandblasted parallel plate (geometry PP08/P2, Ø8
mm) was used instead in the case of the TALG-MCMC hydrogel, to prevent
slipping. The hydrogel disc (Ø8 mm) was placed between the fixed
plate and the measuring plate with a 2 mm gap. In all cases, a solvent
trap device was employed to prevent water evaporation. The assays
were conducted at 37 °C to reproduce the behavior of both the
ink and the hydrogel in cell culture conditions. The amplitude
sweep was performed on the TALG-MCMC ink to identify the linear viscoelastic
(LVE) region over a shear strain range of 0.01 to 100%. To study gelation
kinetics, the TALG-MCMC ink was subjected to a shear strain of 0.1%
within the LVE range and a frequency of 1 Hz. The measurement was
performed over 170 s, with gelation initiated by exposure to a UV
curing lamp at 365 nm after initial 40 s. For the TALG-MCMC hydrogel,
frequency sweeps were conducted in triplicate to determine the storage
modulus ( G G –1 Swelling Test Swelling tests were performed by first
freeze-drying three TALG-MCMC hydrogel samples. These were weighed
before immersing them in cDMEM during 1 h at 37 °C. After incubation
under static conditions, the gels were removed and dried with adsorbent
paper to remove excess of water before being weighed to determine
their mass. This process was repeated at intervals of 2 h, 1 day,
2 days, and 1 week. Throughout the process, it was ensured that the
hydrogels were always fully immersed in cDMEM for optimal diffusion
and the experiments were made in triplicate. The swelling ratio (SR%)
was calculated according to the following equation SR ( % ) = W WET − W DRY W DRY · 100 Bioprinting Fabrication
of the 3D Breast Cancer Model A multihead
3D Discovery bioprinter (RegenHU) was used to print the core/shell
model with integrated plasmonic sensors. The tumoral compartment of
the model contained MDA-MB-231 cells while the stroma was built with
HBF. Before bioprinting, both cell types were fluorescently labeled
with two different cell trackers: MDA-MB-231 were labeled with Cell
Tracker Blue CMF 2 6 6 3 Bioprinting
of the Pillars in the 3D Tumor-Stroma Model The previous
model was heated at 37 °C for 15 min to allow the
extruded dECM to pre-cross-link. Subsequently, the TALG-MCMC ink was
used to print the sensors in the tumoral and stromal compartments.
The sensors were printed as a cylinder (6 layers) of 0.4 mm in diameter,
using a high-precision dispenser plunger through a dispensing needle
with an internal diameter of 0.6 mm (20GA) (Nordson), at a plunger
velocity of 0.0172 mm/s with no retraction distance (0 mm) and a volume
flow rate of 0.780 μL/s. The cylindrical sensors were cross-linked
with UV light during 2.4 s upon deposition of the entire cylinder
using a light curing cartridge at 405 nm wavelength with a power density
of 25.3 mW/cm 2 Incubation
of the Models with 6-TG For the incubation
of 6-TG within the sensors embedded in dECM, 6-TG (50 mM in DMSO stock)
was diluted in dECM (270 μL) to the desired final concentration
(5 μM to 1 mM), prior to printing the sensors. After the printing,
the models were swollen in complete DMEM to reproduce the conditions
of the cellular incubation. For the incubation of breast cancer cell
models with 6-TG, 1 day after being printed, the models were either
treated with the drug or its vehicle. The treated models were swollen
with a solution of 400 μM 6-TG in 1%(v/v) DMSO-containing cDMEM.
Control models were incubated with vehicle (1% (v/v) DMSO-containing
cDMEM). Both control and treated types of models were kept on culture
for over 6 days and subjected to the SERS/fluorescence microscopy
measurements. To investigate the differences in drug uptake between
the core and the stroma, we calculated the average spectra of the
intensity maps at the top of the sensors (highest signal). From these
average spectra we calculated the area under the peak at 1303 cm –1 Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS) Prior to
starting the bioprinting process, homemade holders were arranged on
top of quartz slides. Measurements were made using the backscattering
configuration of the instrument and a Renishaw 1014 CCD Camera using
a 1024 × 256 detector with a grating of 1200 l/mm and slit opening
of 65 μm. All measurements were conducted through a Leica 40×
immersion objective, with a working distance of 3 mm and a numerical
aperture of 1.4. The spectra were collected using a 785 nm laser at
100% power (205 mW/μm 2 Figure Figure r 3 Figure r Confocal Fluorescence Microscopy
Imaging Confocal laser
scanning fluorescence microscopy imaging was performed with a LSM880
microscope (Zeiss), equipped with Ar + Scanning Electron Microscopy Sample
Preparation TALG-MCMC hydrogels were freeze-dried.
The dECM samples were collected at different time points as indicated
(1, 7, or 11 days in vitro 4 Safety Warning Osmium tetroxide
solutions and their
vapors are highly toxic and severe irritants. All skin and eye contact
must be strictly avoided by following safety precautions: Osmium tetroxide
must only be handled in a fume hood and with full PPE (double gloves,
lab coat, and chemical splash goggles). Furthermore, all waste should
be neutralized with oil (seed oil, corn oil, etc Lastly, the sample was washed again with
Milli-Q water three times at 30 min each. While such long formaldehyde/glutaraldehyde
fixations and high concentrations of osmium tetroxide can lead to
overfixation, causing cell shrinkage and various artifacts relevant
to histology or light microscopy characterization, we applied these
quantities and incubation times to ensure that the fixative penetrated
the entire 3D volume of the sample. In fact, when shorter fixation
times were used, difficulties were encountered identifying cells deep
within the sample, and cells appeared damaged. SEM Measurements SEM images of the freeze-dried dECMs
were obtained with a JSM-IT800HL from JEOL (Tokyo, Japan), equipped
with a backscatter electron detector (BSE detector, scintillator-photomultiplier
detector design) and an elevated side-view position a detector (SE
detector, Everhart–Thornley (E-T) detector design) using 3–5
kV, under high vacuum. Statistical Analysis Bar graphs display mean value
± SD. Unpaired Student’s t P P P Supplementary Material Financial support was provided by the European
Research Council
(ERC-AdG-2017 #787510 4DBIOSERS and ERC-2023-POC #101138255 3DTUMOUR)
and by the Spanish MICIU/AEI/10.13039/501100011033 and ERDF/EU (Grant
#PID2023-151281OB-I00). C.G.A. thanks the Spanish State Research Agency
for a Juan de la Cierva Incorporación Fellowship (IJC2019-040827-I).
L.T.A. thanks the Spanish Ministry of Universities for a Formación
de Profesorado Universitario Fellowship (FPU-05867). G.A.V.-W. acknowledges
support from the European Union’s Horizon Europe Research and
Innovation Program under the Marie Skłodowska-Curie grant agreement
no. 101105300 (PLASMOSTEMFATE). The Supporting Information
is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acssensors.5c02344 Additional description
of experimental details and materials,
including characterization of the gold nanoparticles and functionalized
polymers, rheological measurements, details of printing and the SERS
measurements, as well as results of assessing the effect of 6-thioguanine
in 2D cell cultures ( PDF Schemes were produced
